title: Manual Handling Level 2 (UK)
shortDescription: Safe lifting techniques, TILE assessments, and injury prevention in the workplace.
description: Comprehensive manual handling course covering legal requirements, the TILE risk assessment framework, safe lifting techniques, team handling, and use of mechanical aids.
learningOutcomes: Understand the legal requirements for manual handling under the Manual Handling Operations Regulations 1992
Apply the TILE assessment framework to evaluate manual handling risks
Demonstrate safe lifting, carrying, pushing, and pulling techniques
Recognise when to use mechanical aids or team lifting
Identify musculoskeletal disorders and repetitive strain injuries caused by poor manual handling
Report injuries and near misses through the correct channels

modules.title: Introduction and Legal Framework
modules.description: Why manual handling injuries are so common and the law that protects you.

slides.title: Welcome
slides.content:
## Manual Handling Level 2 (UK)

Manual handling injuries account for over **30% of all workplace injuries** reported to the HSE each year. In hospitality alone, thousands of workers suffer back injuries, muscle strains, and repetitive strain injuries that can be debilitating and career-ending.

### What you'll learn
- **The law** -- Manual Handling Operations Regulations 1992 and employer/employee duties.
- **TILE framework** -- Task, Individual, Load, Environment -- the industry-standard risk assessment tool.
- **Safe technique** -- Kinetic lifting, stable base, smooth movements, and correct posture.
- **Team handling** -- Coordination, communication, and shared lifts.
- **Mechanical aids** -- Trolleys, hoists, pallet trucks, and kitchen-specific equipment.
- **MSDs and RSI** -- Recognising musculoskeletal disorders and repetitive strain injuries.
- **Reporting** -- RIDDOR, accident books, and near-miss reporting.

This course will give you the knowledge and confidence to protect yourself and your colleagues every shift.
slides.keyTakeaway: Over 30% of all workplace injuries are caused by manual handling -- most are entirely preventable with the right knowledge.

slides.title: The Scale of the Problem
slides.content:
## Why Manual Handling Training Matters

The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) publishes statistics every year that highlight the scale of the problem:

### Key UK Statistics
- **470,000+** workers suffer from work-related musculoskeletal disorders (MSDs) annually.
- **6.6 million** working days are lost each year due to MSDs.
- **Manual handling** is the single largest cause of over-3-day injuries reported under RIDDOR.
- Back injuries alone cost UK businesses an estimated **GBP 1 billion** per year.

### In Hospitality and Catering
- Chefs and kitchen porters regularly handle loads of 20-30kg (flour sacks, stock pots, delivery crates).
- Repetitive tasks like plating, chopping, and carrying trays cause cumulative strain.
- Wet floors, cramped spaces, and time pressure increase the risk of accidents.
- Bar staff lift kegs (up to 50kg), cases of bottles, and move furniture for events.

### The Human Cost
Beyond statistics, a serious back injury can end a career, affect your ability to play with your children, and cause chronic pain for life. Prevention is always better than treatment.
slides.keyTakeaway: 470,000 UK workers suffer musculoskeletal disorders every year -- hospitality workers are at especially high risk.

slides.title: Manual Handling Operations Regulations 1992
slides.content:
## MHOR 1992 (as amended 2002)

The **Manual Handling Operations Regulations 1992** are the primary UK legislation covering manual handling at work. They sit under the umbrella of the **Health and Safety at Work etc. Act 1974** and the **Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999**.

### The MHOR Hierarchy
Employers must follow a strict three-step hierarchy:

1. **AVOID** -- Eliminate hazardous manual handling operations wherever reasonably practicable. Can the task be redesigned so no one needs to lift?
2. **ASSESS** -- Where manual handling cannot be avoided, carry out a suitable and sufficient risk assessment.
3. **REDUCE** -- Reduce the risk of injury to the lowest level reasonably practicable through controls, equipment, and training.

### Key Legal Points
- The regulations apply to **all** manual handling -- not just heavy lifting. Pushing, pulling, carrying, and holding are all covered.
- A risk assessment must be **recorded** if you employ 5 or more people.
- Assessments must be **reviewed** if there is a significant change or if an injury occurs.
- There are **no legal maximum weight limits** in UK law -- only HSE guidelines.
slides.keyTakeaway: The law requires employers to AVOID, then ASSESS, then REDUCE manual handling risks -- in that order.

slides.title: Employer and Employee Duties
slides.content:
## Who Is Responsible?

### Employer Duties (MHOR Reg 4)
- Carry out manual handling **risk assessments** for all tasks that cannot be avoided.
- Provide appropriate **training** and refresher training.
- Supply **mechanical aids** (trolleys, hoists, pallet trucks) where reasonably practicable.
- **Monitor and review** controls regularly and after any incident.
- Ensure the workplace layout minimises unnecessary manual handling (e.g., store heavy items at waist height).
- Provide **information** to employees about the weight and centre of gravity of loads.

### Employee Duties (MHOR Reg 5 + HSWA s.7)
- **Follow** the training and safe systems of work provided.
- **Use** equipment provided (trolleys, gloves, lifting aids).
- **Report** any injury, near miss, or concern to your manager.
- **Do not** take unnecessary risks -- if it feels too heavy, stop and get help.
- **Co-operate** with your employer on health and safety matters.
- Do not **misuse** anything provided for safety.

### Enforcement
The HSE and local authorities enforce the regulations. Breaches can result in **improvement notices**, **prohibition notices**, and prosecution with **unlimited fines** and up to **2 years imprisonment**.
slides.keyTakeaway: Employers must assess and control risks; employees must follow training, use equipment, and report problems.

slides.title: RIDDOR and Reporting
slides.content:
## Reporting Injuries

### RIDDOR (Reporting of Injuries, Diseases and Dangerous Occurrences Regulations 2013)
Certain manual handling injuries **must** be reported to the HSE under RIDDOR:

- **Deaths** -- Must be reported immediately.
- **Specified injuries** -- Fractures (except fingers/toes), dislocations, amputations, crush injuries, loss of consciousness.
- **Over-7-day incapacitation** -- If a worker is unable to work for more than 7 consecutive days (not counting the day of injury).
- **Occupational diseases** -- Including carpal tunnel syndrome and severe cramp of the hand/forearm from repetitive work.

### Internal Reporting
- **Accident book** -- All injuries, however minor, must be recorded in the workplace accident book.
- **Near misses** -- Report situations where injury was narrowly avoided (e.g., a heavy box nearly fell on someone).
- **Verbal report** -- Tell your supervisor or manager immediately.

### Why Reporting Matters
- Identifies patterns and recurring problems.
- Triggers risk assessment reviews.
- Provides legal evidence if needed.
- Helps prevent the same injury happening to someone else.
slides.keyTakeaway: All injuries must go in the accident book. Serious injuries must also be reported to the HSE under RIDDOR.

start.text: It's 7am and a delivery driver has left 20 heavy crates outside the kitchen back door. Your shift starts in 10 minutes and the head chef wants everything put away before service prep begins. The crates weigh roughly 25kg each. What do you do?

options.label: Start carrying them in by yourself as fast as possible to impress the chef.
Ask a colleague to help and use the kitchen trolley to move the crates inside.
Leave them outside until someone with more experience deals with them.

rush_alone.text:
You grab the first crate and feel your back strain immediately. 25kg is near the HSE guideline limit for an ideal lift -- and this is far from ideal. The crates are awkward, the floor is wet from overnight rain, and you are rushing.

What do you do now?

options.label: Keep going -- you've started now and don't want to look weak.
Stop, put the crate down, and reassess. Get help and equipment.

injury.text:
On the fifth crate, you twist awkwardly to avoid a puddle and feel a sharp pain in your lower back. You've strained your lumbar muscles. This injury could keep you off work for weeks.

**Key lesson**: Time pressure is never an excuse to skip safe handling. The MHOR hierarchy (avoid, assess, reduce) applies even when you're busy. Your employer has a legal duty to provide equipment and training -- and you have a duty to use them.

options.label: Start Over

recover.text:
Good decision. You recognised the risk and stopped before getting injured. You fetch the trolley and ask a colleague to help. Together, you move all 20 crates safely in half the time it would have taken alone.

**Key lesson**: It takes courage to stop and reassess, but it's always the right call. Regulation 5 of MHOR requires employees to use equipment provided and not take unnecessary risks.

team_trolley.text:
Excellent. You and your colleague use the trolley to wheel crates inside, then stack them at waist height. The wet area near the door is dried before you start.

**You applied the TILE framework without even realising it:**
- **Task**: Repetitive heavy lifting -- use a trolley to reduce it.
- **Individual**: You got help rather than working alone.
- **Load**: 25kg crates -- near the limit, so equipment is essential.
- **Environment**: Wet floor -- you dried it first.

This is exactly what the law requires.

leave_them.text:
Leaving deliveries unattended outside creates new hazards -- they could block fire exits, get stolen, or become a trip hazard. While you should never rush into unsafe manual handling, ignoring the task entirely is not the answer.

What should you do instead?

options.label: Tell your manager and work together with equipment to bring them in safely.
Just carry a few in to show willing, then leave the rest.

start.text: You strained your shoulder two days ago while lifting a heavy stockpot. It still hurts but you can work through it. A colleague tells you not to bother reporting it because 'everyone gets aches and pains in this job'. What do you do?

options.label: Agree with your colleague and carry on -- it's just a minor ache.
Report it to your manager and record it in the accident book.
Take some painkillers and see if it gets better by next week.

ignore.text:
Over the next few weeks, the pain gets worse. You start compensating by using your other arm, which causes a new strain. Eventually you need three weeks off work.

Because the original injury was never recorded, your employer has no documentation. The risk assessment for stockpot handling was never reviewed, and another colleague suffers the same injury the following month.

What should you have done?

options.label: Reported it immediately and got it in the accident book.

report.text:
Your manager records the injury in the accident book and reviews the risk assessment for stockpot handling. They discover that the stockpot is routinely filled beyond a safe weight. A ladle-and-decant procedure is introduced, and a smaller pot is purchased for lighter batches.

**Key lesson**: Every injury -- even a 'minor' one -- must be reported. Under RIDDOR, if you are incapacitated for more than 7 days, your employer must report it to the HSE. Early reporting triggers early action and prevents repeat injuries.

delay.text:
A week later, the pain is worse. You finally tell your manager, but now the details are fuzzy -- when exactly did it happen? What were you lifting? How full was the pot?

Late reporting makes it harder to:
- Complete an accurate accident book entry.
- Review the specific risk assessment.
- Meet RIDDOR deadlines if the injury worsens.

What should you do now?

options.label: Report it immediately, even though it's late -- better late than never.

late_report.text:
Your manager appreciates the honesty and records what they can. The risk assessment is reviewed and improvements are made. However, the delay meant the initial details were less accurate.

**Key lesson**: Always report injuries as soon as possible. Prompt reporting leads to accurate records and faster corrective action. Never let a culture of 'just get on with it' override your legal right to a safe workplace.

modules.title: The TILE Framework
modules.description: Assessing manual handling risks systematically using the TILE acronym.

slides.title: The TILE Acronym
slides.content:
## Task, Individual, Load, Environment

The **TILE** framework is the standard tool for assessing manual handling risks. Before any manual handling task, work through all four elements systematically.

The HSE guidance document **L23 (Manual Handling: Guidance on Regulations)** recommends TILE as the basis for all manual handling risk assessments.

### How to use TILE
1. **Stop** before you lift, push, pull, or carry.
2. **Assess** each of the four TILE elements.
3. **Decide** whether you can do the task safely or whether you need to change something.
4. **Act** -- modify the task, get help, use equipment, or refuse if it's unsafe.

The following slides break down each element in detail with hospitality-specific examples.
slides.keyTakeaway: TILE: Task, Individual, Load, Environment -- assess all four before every manual handling operation.

slides.title: T -- Task
slides.content:
## What Does the Task Involve?

Consider the physical demands of the activity itself:

### Questions to Ask
- Does the task involve **twisting**, **stooping**, **bending**, or **reaching**?
- How far must the load be **moved**? (Long carry distances increase fatigue.)
- Is there **pushing**, **pulling**, **carrying**, or **holding for long periods**?
- Does the task require **sudden movements** or **precise positioning**?
- Is it **repetitive**? (Doing the same lift 50 times is more dangerous than doing it once.)
- Does it involve lifting from **floor level** or placing above **shoulder height**?

### Hospitality Examples
- **Twisting**: Turning from a prep counter to put pans in the oven behind you.
- **Stooping**: Picking up crates from a low delivery pallet.
- **Repetitive**: Plating 200 covers, each requiring a lift-and-carry of a heavy plate.
- **Long carry**: Moving supplies from a distant storeroom to the kitchen.

### Red Flags
If the task requires you to twist, bend, and lift simultaneously, the risk is **significantly higher**. Redesign the task or use equipment.
slides.keyTakeaway: Assess the physical demands: twisting, stooping, distance, repetition, and duration all increase risk.

slides.title: I -- Individual
slides.content:
## Who Is Doing the Handling?

Not everyone has the same physical capability. The assessment must consider the individual.

### Questions to Ask
- Are you **fit and well** enough for this task today?
- Do you have any **existing injuries**, conditions, or disabilities?
- Are you **pregnant**? (Regulation 16 of the Management Regulations gives specific protection to new and expectant mothers.)
- Have you been **trained** in safe manual handling techniques?
- Are you wearing appropriate **clothing and footwear**? (Non-slip shoes, no loose clothing.)
- What is your **age** and **physical fitness** level?
- Are you **fatigued** from a long shift?

### Hospitality Examples
- A chef with a pre-existing back condition should not lift heavy stockpots alone.
- A new starter who hasn't received manual handling training must not be asked to unload deliveries unsupervised.
- A pregnant member of staff must have their risk assessment updated to reflect manual handling restrictions.
- A team member at the end of a 12-hour double shift is at higher risk of injury due to fatigue.

### Key Point
The law does not set different weight limits for men and women, but the HSE guidelines acknowledge that **physical capability varies** between individuals. Never feel pressured to lift beyond your ability.
slides.keyTakeaway: Consider your fitness, existing injuries, training, fatigue, and whether you are physically capable of the task.

slides.title: L -- Load
slides.content:
## What Are You Handling?

The characteristics of the load itself affect how risky the task is.

### Questions to Ask
- How **heavy** is it? (If you don't know, check the label or ask.)
- Is it **bulky**, **awkward**, or an **unusual shape**?
- Can you get a **good grip** on it? (Smooth, wet, or greasy surfaces reduce grip.)
- Is the **weight evenly distributed**? (Liquids in half-full containers slosh and shift.)
- Is the load **hot**, **cold**, or **sharp**?
- Does it have **handles** or handholds?
- Is it **fragile** or does it contain **hazardous contents**?

### Hospitality Examples
- **Awkward shape**: A full gastronorm tray of roasted vegetables -- wide and hot.
- **Shifting weight**: A half-full stockpot of soup -- liquid sloshes when you move.
- **Poor grip**: A wet, greasy baking tray straight from the dishwasher.
- **Hot load**: A large pot of boiling stock -- scalding risk compounds the manual handling risk.
- **No handles**: A 25kg sack of flour with no grip points.

### HSE Weight Guidelines (Not Legal Limits)
The HSE provides guideline weights based on the position of the load relative to the body:
- **Close to body, waist height**: 25kg (men), 16kg (women).
- **At arm's length**: Roughly 50% lower.
- **Above shoulder or below knee**: Significantly lower.

These are **guidelines for ideal conditions** -- if any TILE factor is unfavourable, reduce the weight further.
slides.keyTakeaway: Check the weight, shape, grip, stability, and temperature of the load before handling it.

slides.title: E -- Environment
slides.content:
## Where Is the Task Taking Place?

The physical environment can turn a manageable lift into a dangerous one.

### Questions to Ask
- Is the floor **wet**, **greasy**, **uneven**, or **cluttered**?
- Are there **stairs**, **slopes**, **ramps**, or **steps** on the route?
- Are **doorways** and **corridors** wide enough for the load?
- Is there adequate **lighting**? (Can you see where you're going?)
- Is the **temperature extreme**? (Hot kitchens cause sweaty hands; walk-in freezers make you stiffer.)
- Is there enough **space** to adopt a good lifting posture?
- Are there **obstructions**, trip hazards, or other people in the way?
- Is there a **significant height difference** between pick-up and put-down points?

### Hospitality Examples
- **Wet floors**: Kitchen floors near sinks, dishwashers, and pot-wash areas.
- **Cramped spaces**: Narrow storerooms where you can't bend your knees properly.
- **Temperature extremes**: Carrying boxes in and out of a walk-in freezer at -18 degrees C.
- **Poor lighting**: Dimly lit cellar stairs when moving kegs.
- **Obstructions**: Busy service with waiters crossing your path as you carry a heavy tray.

### Control the Environment First
Many injuries happen because of the environment, not the load. Before lifting, clear the route, dry wet floors, ensure lighting is adequate, and remove obstructions.
slides.keyTakeaway: Wet floors, poor lighting, cramped spaces, and temperature extremes can make any manual handling task dangerous.

slides.title: Scenario: The Heavy Delivery in the Rain

start.text: A 30kg delivery crate has arrived during heavy rain. The floor near the back door is soaking wet, the crate has no handles, and you've just come off a double shift. A colleague offers to help. What do you do?

options.label: Lift it quickly by yourself before anyone notices the mess -- you've done heavier lifts before.
Dry the floor, get the trolley, and work with your colleague to wheel it inside.
Drag the crate along the wet floor to avoid lifting it at all.

solo_wet.text:
You attempt to lift the 30kg crate alone. The lack of handles forces you into an awkward grip. As you step onto the wet floor, your foot slips slightly and you compensate by twisting your torso.

Let's assess using TILE:
- **Task**: Lifting 30kg with no handles requires twisting.
- **Individual**: You're fatigued from a double shift.
- **Load**: 30kg, no handles, awkward grip.
- **Environment**: Wet floor, rain.

Every TILE factor is against you. What now?

options.label: Put it down immediately and reassess.
Power through -- you're nearly there.

slip_injury.text:
Your foot slips on the wet floor. To stop yourself falling, you jerk the crate to one side, causing a sharp pain in your lower back. You drop the crate and it lands on your foot.

**Result**: Strained back and bruised foot. Two weeks off work. Your employer must report this under RIDDOR because you are incapacitated for more than 7 days.

**Key lesson**: Every TILE factor was unfavourable. The law required your employer to provide equipment and a safe working environment. Your duty was to refuse the unsafe task and use what was available.

options.label: Start Over

correct_approach.text:
You mop and dry the wet area near the back door. Your colleague brings the kitchen trolley. Together, you slide the crate onto the trolley (keeping it at waist height) and wheel it to the storeroom.

**TILE assessment:**
- **Task**: Pushing a trolley instead of lifting 30kg -- much lower risk.
- **Individual**: Two people sharing the task; fatigue mitigated.
- **Load**: Crate is on the trolley, no need to grip it.
- **Environment**: Floor is now dry, route is clear.

You turned a high-risk operation into a low-risk one. This is exactly what the MHOR hierarchy requires: reduce risk to the lowest level reasonably practicable.

drag.text:
Dragging the crate across a wet floor creates several new hazards:
- The pushing/pulling force on a wet surface is unpredictable.
- You could slip and fall.
- The crate could damage the floor or its contents.
- Dragging puts significant strain on your back and shoulders.

Dragging is not a safe alternative to lifting. What should you do instead?

options.label: Use the trolley and get help from your colleague.
Just lift it -- dragging clearly isn't working.

start.text: You need to move 15 boxes of frozen goods from a delivery pallet into the walk-in freezer. Each box weighs about 12kg. The freezer is at -18 degrees C, the shelves inside range from floor level to above head height, and you're the only person available right now. How do you approach this?

options.label: Carry two boxes at once to get it done faster -- 12kg each isn't that heavy.
Take one box at a time, assess the freezer layout, and use a step stool for high shelves.
Stack all 15 boxes on the floor of the freezer and sort them out later.

two_boxes.text:
Carrying two 12kg boxes simultaneously means 24kg with a significantly reduced grip and obscured forward vision. Inside the freezer at -18 degrees C, the floor may be icy and your hands will quickly lose dexterity.

By the eighth trip, your fingers are numb and you fumble a box. It falls, scattering frozen goods across the freezer floor -- now a trip hazard.

What should you do?

options.label: Clean up, take one box at a time, and limit your time in the freezer.
Kick the fallen items aside and keep going.

freezer_slip.text:
You step on a frozen packet on the icy floor and slip, landing hard on your hip. In a -18 degrees C freezer, you're alone, injured, and the cold is making things worse.

**Key lesson**: Multiple TILE factors were against you -- the extreme cold (environment), carrying double loads (task), loss of grip (individual), and no handles on stacked boxes (load). Working alone in a freezer without telling anyone is an additional safety risk. Always tell someone before entering a confined cold space.

options.label: Start Over

methodical.text:
You take one box at a time, keeping each close to your body. You use the step stool for shelves above shoulder height. You limit your time in the freezer to avoid numbness, taking breaks to warm your hands. Heavy items go on the middle shelves at waist height; lighter items go higher and lower.

**Excellent TILE assessment:**
- **Task**: One box per trip reduces strain; step stool avoids overhead reaching.
- **Individual**: Regular warm-up breaks maintain dexterity and alertness.
- **Load**: 12kg per box is manageable with good technique.
- **Environment**: You acknowledged the freezer hazards (cold, potential ice) and worked carefully.

You also stored heavy items at waist height -- reducing future manual handling risk for everyone who uses the freezer.

floor_dump.text:
Dumping all boxes on the freezer floor creates several problems:
- The floor becomes an obstacle course -- serious slip and trip hazard.
- You (or a colleague) will still need to lift each box onto shelves later.
- Items on the floor are harder to lift (below knee height increases spinal load by 50% compared to waist height).
- Food stored on the floor can be contaminated and fails food safety regulations.

This approach just delays and worsens the manual handling task. What should you do instead?

options.label: Take one box at a time and put each directly on the correct shelf.
Carry two at a time to get it over with quickly.

modules.title: Safe Lifting, Carrying, and Moving Techniques
modules.description: How to lift, carry, push, pull, and work as a team safely.

slides.title: Step-by-Step Safe Lifting
slides.content:
## The Kinetic Lifting Technique

The kinetic lifting technique uses the body's natural mechanics to minimise strain on the spine. Follow these steps for every lift:

### Before the Lift
1. **Plan the lift** -- Where are you going? Is the route clear? Do you need help or equipment?
2. **Position yourself** -- Stand close to the load with a **stable base** (feet shoulder-width apart, one foot slightly forward for balance).

### The Lift
3. **Bend your knees**, not your back. Lower yourself by bending at the hips and knees while keeping your back straight and naturally curved.
4. **Get a firm grip** -- Use your whole hand (palm grip), not just fingertips. If the load is smooth or wet, use gloves.
5. **Brace your core** -- Tighten your abdominal muscles before lifting to support your spine.
6. **Lift smoothly** using your **leg muscles**. Straighten your knees and hips together. Keep the load **close to your body** throughout.
7. **Keep your head up** and look ahead, not down at the load.

### While Moving
8. **Move your feet** to turn -- **never twist your body** while carrying.
9. Take small, steady steps. Avoid sudden movements.

### Setting Down
10. **Reverse the process** -- Bend your knees, position the load, then release your grip.
slides.keyTakeaway: Lift with your legs, keep the load close to your body, brace your core, and never twist -- protect your spine.

slides.title: HSE Weight Guidelines
slides.content:
## Understanding the Weight-Zone Chart

The HSE publishes guideline weights based on **where the load is held relative to the body**. These are for an **ideal lift** (load close to body, good grip, no twisting, good environment).

### Men (Guideline Figures)
| Zone | Close to Body | At Arm's Length |
|------|--------------|----------------|
| Shoulder height | 10kg | 5kg |
| Elbow height | 20kg | 10kg |
| Knuckle height | 25kg | 15kg |
| Mid-lower leg | 10kg | 5kg |

### Women (Guideline Figures)
| Zone | Close to Body | At Arm's Length |
|------|--------------|----------------|
| Shoulder height | 7kg | 3kg |
| Elbow height | 13kg | 7kg |
| Knuckle height | 16kg | 10kg |
| Mid-lower leg | 7kg | 3kg |

### Critical Points
- These are **guidelines**, not legal limits. The actual safe weight depends on all TILE factors.
- If the task involves **twisting**, reduce the weight by **10-20%**.
- If the task is **repetitive** (more than once per minute), reduce further.
- The figures assume a **one-off lift by a fit, healthy person**.
- When in doubt, **use equipment or get help**.
slides.keyTakeaway: The HSE guideline for men at waist height is 25kg close to body -- but any unfavourable TILE factor reduces this.

slides.title: Carrying Safely
slides.content:
## Moving a Load Over Distance

Carrying adds fatigue to the equation. The longer the carry distance, the greater the risk.

### Safe Carrying Principles
- Keep the load **close to your body** at waist height where possible.
- Maintain an **upright posture** -- do not lean back to counterbalance.
- Ensure you can **see over** the load (or around it). If you can't, the load is too bulky to carry alone.
- Take the **shortest safe route** -- plan before you pick up.
- Use **two hands** wherever possible for balance.
- If carrying on stairs, ensure one hand is free for the **handrail** -- or use a trolley and the lift.

### Hospitality-Specific Carrying Tasks
- **Plate carrying**: Use trays rather than stacking plates on your arm for heavy items.
- **Tray service**: Balance the tray on your palm at shoulder height; keep your elbow close to your body.
- **Hot liquids**: Use a trolley for large soup pots. If carrying, ensure the lid is secure and the route is clear.
- **Keg moving**: Never carry a full keg (50kg). Use a keg trolley or barrel roller.

### The 10-Metre Rule
If the carry distance exceeds 10 metres, the HSE recommends using a trolley or other wheeled equipment.
slides.keyTakeaway: Keep the load close, maintain an upright posture, see where you are going, and use a trolley for distances over 10 metres.

slides.title: Pushing and Pulling
slides.content:
## Push, Don't Pull

Whenever possible, **push** rather than **pull**. Pushing allows you to use your body weight, see where you are going, and maintain a better posture.

### Safe Pushing and Pulling Technique
- Keep your feet **shoulder-width apart** with one foot forward.
- **Lean into the load** slightly when pushing (use your body weight).
- Use your **legs and body weight**, not just your arms.
- Apply the force at **waist to chest height** -- not too high, not too low.
- Use equipment **handles** where available.
- Keep the load **in front of you** so you can see the route.
- Start slowly and build momentum -- the initial push is the hardest.

### When Pulling is Necessary
- Sometimes you must pull (e.g., pulling a loaded trolley through a doorway).
- Face the direction of travel if possible.
- Keep your back straight and pull with your legs.
- Avoid pulling loads up slopes where possible -- push instead.

### HSE Push/Pull Guidelines
- For **starting a load on a flat surface**: men approximately 20kg force; women approximately 15kg force.
- For **keeping it moving**: men approximately 10kg sustained force; women approximately 7kg sustained force.
- Equipment with **good wheels and bearings** significantly reduces the force needed.
slides.keyTakeaway: Push rather than pull wherever possible -- use your body weight, keep the force at waist height, and maintain good posture.

slides.title: Team Lifting and Coordination
slides.content:
## When One Person Is Not Enough

Team handling is required when a load is too heavy, too bulky, or too awkward for one person. However, team lifts introduce coordination risks that must be managed.

### Team Lifting Rules
1. **Designate a leader** -- One person gives all commands. Everyone follows the same instructions.
2. **Communicate clearly** -- Use agreed commands: 'Ready? Lift. Walk. Stop. Set down.'
3. **Lift and lower at the same time** -- The leader counts: 'One, two, three, lift.'
4. **Match heights where possible** -- If heights differ, the taller person takes the heavier end.
5. **Plan the route together** -- Everyone must know where the load is going before you start.
6. **Walk in step** -- Move at the same pace to keep the load stable.

### How Many People?
- Team handling does **not** double the safe weight for two people. Two people can safely handle approximately **two-thirds** of their combined individual capacities (due to coordination losses).
- For example, two people who can each safely lift 25kg individually should not exceed approximately 33kg together (not 50kg).

### Hospitality Examples
- **Banqueting tables**: Minimum two people, folding legs secured before carrying.
- **Large stock pots**: Two people with a pole or handles.
- **Commercial oven trays**: Two people wearing heat-resistant gloves.
- **Barrel/keg moving**: Two people with a keg trolley, never free-carrying.
slides.keyTakeaway: Designate a leader, use clear commands, lift together, and remember: two people does NOT mean double the safe weight.

start.text: The restaurant has a private event tonight. You need to rearrange 12 heavy banqueting tables from the storeroom to the function room. The tables weigh about 35kg each and are bulky. The route involves a narrow corridor and a set of double doors. How do you approach this?

options.label: Carry each table by yourself -- it's only a short walk and you're strong enough.
Get a colleague, plan the route, and use a flatbed trolley for transport.
Drag the tables along the floor -- sliding is easier than lifting.

solo_carry.text:
35kg is well above the HSE guideline for most lifting scenarios, and banqueting tables are bulky with no easy grip points. On the first carry, the table catches on the narrow corridor wall and you have to twist sideways to get through.

Your back is already aching after three tables. You still have nine to go. What do you do?

options.label: Stop and get help. Use the flatbed trolley.
Take painkillers and push through -- the event is tonight.

back_injury.text:
On the seventh table, you feel a sharp, shooting pain from your lower back down your leg. You've compressed a disc. This type of injury can take months to heal and may require surgery.

**Key lesson**: 35kg exceeds safe individual lifting guidelines. The bulky shape, narrow corridor, and repetition (12 tables) made this a high-risk task from the start. Equipment and teamwork were essential. Painkillers mask the warning signs your body sends -- they do not reduce the risk of injury.

options.label: Start Over

planned.text:
You and your colleague survey the route: the corridor is clear, and you prop open the double doors with approved door-holding devices. You load two tables at a time onto the flatbed trolley and wheel them to the function room.

For placement, you work together: one person leads with 'Ready, walk, stop, set down' commands. The taller colleague takes the heavier end.

**Result**: All 12 tables moved safely in 25 minutes. No injuries, no rushing. The event is set up on time.

**Key lesson**: Planning, teamwork, and equipment turned a high-risk, 35kg solo-lift task into a low-risk, wheeled-transport operation. This is exactly what MHOR requires.

drag_tables.text:
Dragging a 35kg table along the floor causes several problems:
- The legs catch on floor surfaces and doorframes, requiring sudden jerking movements.
- Dragging forces are unpredictable and strain your back and shoulders.
- You're damaging the floor, the table, and potentially the door frames.
- The pushing/pulling forces on the corridor carpet are very high.

Your manager notices and asks you to stop. What do you do?

options.label: Get the trolley and a colleague, then do it properly.
Try carrying them instead since dragging isn't allowed.

start.text: A chef asks you to move a large stockpot from the stove to the cold prep area. The pot is nearly full of hot liquid (about 80 degrees C), weighs approximately 20kg, and the handles are hot. The distance is about 8 metres across a busy kitchen during lunch service. What do you do?

options.label: Grab the handles with a dry cloth and carry it across the kitchen.
Use heat-resistant gloves, get a colleague to clear the route, and carry it together.
Ladle the contents into smaller containers and carry those instead.

cloth_carry.text:
A dry cloth provides poor insulation and can slip off the handles. As you carry the 20kg pot of near-boiling liquid across a busy kitchen, a waiter steps into your path. You swerve, the cloth slips, and hot liquid splashes onto your arm.

This is now both a manual handling injury and a burn injury. What should you have done?

options.label: Used proper heat-resistant gloves and cleared the route first.
Decanted into smaller containers before moving.

team_careful.text:
You put on heat-resistant gloves and ask a colleague to walk ahead, clearing the route and warning other staff. Together, you carry the pot at waist height with steady steps.

This is a reasonable approach, but consider: could the risk be reduced further?

**Better practice**: If your kitchen has a pot trolley, use it. If not, decanting into smaller containers eliminates the risk of carrying a heavy, hot load. The MHOR hierarchy says avoid first, then reduce.

decant.text:
Excellent decision. By ladling the hot liquid into smaller, lighter containers (e.g., 4-5 litre jugs with lids), you have:

- **Reduced the weight** from 20kg to manageable 4-5kg portions.
- **Reduced the burn risk** -- smaller volumes are easier to control and less dangerous if spilled.
- **Eliminated** the need for a heavy two-person carry across a busy kitchen.

**This applies the MHOR hierarchy perfectly**: you couldn't avoid moving the liquid, so you reduced the risk by changing the method. HSE guidance (L23) specifically recommends breaking large loads into smaller ones where possible.

splash_injury.text: Hot liquid burns cause serious injuries. Under RIDDOR, burns requiring hospital treatment or causing over-7-day incapacitation must be reported to the HSE. Prevention through proper equipment and technique is always the priority.

options.label: Start Over

modules.title: Mechanical Aids, Ergonomics, and Good Practice
modules.description: Using equipment, preventing repetitive strain, and building safe habits for the long term.

slides.title: Use the Right Equipment
slides.content:
## Reducing Manual Handling with Mechanical Aids

The **best way** to prevent a manual handling injury is to **avoid manual handling** entirely. The MHOR hierarchy puts this first for good reason.

### Common Mechanical Aids
- **Sack trucks / hand trucks** -- For moving boxes, crates, and sacks vertically and over short distances.
- **Flatbed trolleys** -- For moving multiple items or heavy/bulky loads horizontally.
- **Pallet trucks** -- For heavy palletised deliveries (can handle up to 2,500kg).
- **Hoists and lifts** -- For very heavy or repetitive lifting tasks (e.g., goods lifts between floors).
- **Conveyor belts / roller tracks** -- In production and warehouse environments.
- **Step stools / kick steps** -- To avoid overhead reaching and lifting above shoulder height.
- **Keg trolleys / barrel rollers** -- Specifically designed for moving kegs (40-50kg) safely.

### Your Duty
If your employer provides mechanical aids, you **must** use them. Under MHOR Regulation 5, employees have a duty to make full and proper use of equipment provided. Choosing not to use a trolley when one is available is a breach of your legal duty.
slides.keyTakeaway: If there is a trolley available, there is no excuse for carrying. Using equipment is a legal duty, not a suggestion.

slides.title: Kitchen and Hospitality-Specific Aids
slides.content:
## Equipment for Your Workplace

### Kitchen
- **Pot stands at floor level** -- Raise heavy pots to avoid lifting from the ground.
- **Pot trolleys** -- Wheeled frames to move heavy stockpots without carrying.
- **Dispensers** -- For heavy sauces, oils, and liquids (pump or tap dispensers reduce lifting).
- **Decanting** -- Break large containers into smaller, manageable portions.
- **Height-adjustable prep tables** -- Reduce stooping and reaching.
- **Tilt kettles** -- Large kettles with a tilting mechanism to pour without lifting.

### Storage and Shelving
- Store **heavy items at waist height** (knuckle to elbow level).
- Store **lighter items** on higher and lower shelves.
- Use **step stools** for items above shoulder height -- never stretch on tiptoes.
- Use **pull-out shelving** or sliding drawers for items stored at low levels.

### Bar and Front of House
- **Keg lifters and trolleys** for beer cellar work.
- **Crate dollies** for moving cases of bottles.
- **Glass-carrying trays** with non-slip surfaces.
- **Linen trolleys** for housekeeping rather than carrying armfuls of sheets.

### Maintenance
- Check wheels, handles, and mechanisms regularly.
- Report damaged equipment immediately.
- Keep trolleys clean and stored in accessible locations.
slides.keyTakeaway: Heavy items at waist height, decant large containers, use dispensers, and always choose the right trolley for the job.

slides.title: Repetitive Strain and Musculoskeletal Disorders
slides.content:
## The Cumulative Danger

Not all manual handling injuries happen from a single heavy lift. Many of the most debilitating conditions develop gradually over weeks, months, or years of **repetitive** activity.

### Musculoskeletal Disorders (MSDs)
MSDs affect muscles, joints, tendons, ligaments, nerves, and the spine. Common work-related MSDs include:

- **Lower back pain** -- The most common MSD; caused by repeated bending, twisting, and lifting.
- **Upper limb disorders (ULDs)** -- Pain in the shoulders, arms, wrists, and hands from repetitive tasks.
- **Carpal tunnel syndrome** -- Compression of the wrist nerve from repetitive hand/wrist movements.
- **Tendonitis** -- Inflammation of tendons from repeated motion (e.g., repetitive chopping, plating).
- **Rotator cuff injuries** -- Shoulder damage from repeated overhead reaching.
- **Herniated (slipped) disc** -- Disc damage from repeated spinal loading.

### Warning Signs
- Persistent aching, pain, or stiffness in your back, neck, shoulders, or hands.
- Numbness, tingling, or 'pins and needles' in your arms or hands.
- Weakness in your grip.
- Swelling or stiffness in joints.

### Key Point
If you experience any of these symptoms, **report them immediately**. Early intervention prevents permanent damage.
slides.keyTakeaway: Repetitive tasks cause cumulative damage over time. Report persistent aches, tingling, or weakness early -- do not wait.

slides.title: Workstation Ergonomics
slides.content:
## Setting Up Your Work Area

Ergonomics is the science of designing work to fit the worker. Poor workstation setup is a major contributor to MSDs.

### Standing Workstation (Kitchen, Bar, Reception)
- Work surface should be at **elbow height** (approximately 90-degree bend at the elbow).
- If the surface is too low, you stoop; too high, and your shoulders hunch.
- Use **anti-fatigue mats** to reduce strain from prolonged standing.
- Keep frequently used items **within arm's reach** to avoid overreaching.
- Change your posture regularly -- shift weight between feet, take micro-breaks.

### Seated Workstation (Office, Reception, Back Office)
- Chair height: feet flat on the floor, thighs horizontal.
- Screen at **arm's length**, top of screen at **eye level**.
- Keyboard and mouse close to the body; elbows at 90 degrees.
- Take regular breaks -- stand and stretch every 30-60 minutes.

### Reducing Repetitive Strain in Hospitality
- **Rotate tasks** -- Alternate between chopping, carrying, and plating.
- **Take micro-breaks** -- Even 30 seconds of stretching between tasks helps.
- **Use sharp knives** -- Blunt knives require more force, increasing hand and wrist strain.
- **Adjust work heights** -- Use risers, chopping boards, or adjustable tables to get the right height.
- **Stretch before shifts** -- Simple stretches for back, shoulders, wrists, and legs reduce injury risk.
slides.keyTakeaway: Work at elbow height, keep items within reach, rotate tasks, and take micro-breaks to prevent repetitive strain.

slides.title: Building Good Habits
slides.content:
## Daily Practices for Long-Term Health

### Before Every Shift
- **Warm up** -- Gentle stretches for your back, shoulders, legs, and wrists (2-3 minutes).
- **Check your PPE** -- Non-slip shoes, appropriate clothing, gloves if needed.
- **Know the layout** -- Where are the trolleys? Is the route to the storeroom clear?

### During Your Shift
- **Think TILE** before every manual handling task -- make it automatic.
- **Ask for help** -- It is not a sign of weakness; it is a legal expectation.
- **Use equipment** -- Trolleys, step stools, dispensers, hoists.
- **Rotate tasks** where possible to avoid prolonged repetitive movements.
- **Stay hydrated** -- Dehydrated muscles are more prone to injury.
- **Report hazards** -- Wet floors, broken equipment, blocked routes.

### After Your Shift
- **Cool down** -- Gentle stretches, especially for your lower back.
- **Report any aches or pains** -- The accident book exists for a reason.
- **Rest** -- Allow your body to recover between shifts.

### The Culture of Safety
A good safety culture means:
- No one is ridiculed for using equipment or asking for help.
- Near misses are reported without blame.
- Training is refreshed annually.
- Equipment is maintained and available.
slides.keyTakeaway: Make TILE assessment automatic, warm up before shifts, report hazards, and never be afraid to ask for help.

start.text: You need to put 10 heavy catering-size tins (each about 3kg) onto a shelf that is above your shoulder height. There is a step stool nearby but using it would take longer. A colleague suggests standing on an upturned crate instead because it's taller. What do you do?

options.label: Stretch up on tiptoes to reach the shelf -- it's only 3kg per tin.
Use the step stool to bring yourself to the right height.
Stand on the upturned crate as your colleague suggested -- it's taller and faster.

tiptoe.text:
Lifting above shoulder height significantly reduces your safe lifting capacity. The HSE guideline drops to just 7kg for men and 3kg for women at shoulder height at arm's length. Stretching on tiptoes also:

- Reduces your grip strength.
- Puts strain on your shoulders and rotator cuffs.
- Makes you unstable -- one wobble and you could drop a tin on yourself or fall.

After placing four tins, your shoulders are burning and you nearly drop the fifth. What now?

options.label: Use the step stool for the remaining tins.
Power through the last six -- you're halfway done.

shoulder_injury.text:
On the eighth tin, you feel a sharp pain in your right shoulder. You've strained your rotator cuff -- a common injury from repeated overhead lifting. This type of injury can take 6-12 weeks to heal and may recur.

**Key lesson**: The HSE weight guidelines exist for a reason. At shoulder height and arm's length, the safe weight is dramatically lower. A step stool takes 30 seconds to set up but prevents weeks of pain.

options.label: Start Over

step_stool.text:
You position the step stool in front of the shelf and step up. Now the shelf is at waist height -- the safest lifting zone. You place all 10 tins comfortably with good posture, keeping each tin close to your body.

**TILE assessment:**
- **Task**: Lifting to waist height (from the step stool) instead of above shoulder height.
- **Individual**: Stable platform, good posture, within your capability.
- **Load**: 3kg per tin -- well within guidelines at waist height.
- **Environment**: Step stool provides a stable, non-slip platform.

Using the step stool took an extra 30 seconds but eliminated the injury risk entirely.

crate.text:
Standing on an upturned crate is extremely dangerous:
- Crates are not designed to bear a person's weight -- they can collapse.
- The surface is uneven and provides no grip.
- There is no handrail or support if you lose balance.
- Falling from a crate while holding a 3kg tin could cause head injuries, broken bones, or worse.

This would also violate the **Working at Height Regulations 2005** -- you must use appropriate equipment (step stools, ladders) for work above ground level.

What should you use instead?

options.label: The step stool -- it's designed for this purpose.
Just stretch up from the floor -- at least that's safer than the crate.

start.text: You've been working as a kitchen porter for three weeks. Every evening after your shift, you notice increasing stiffness and aching in your lower back and numbness in your right wrist. A more experienced colleague says 'Everyone gets that -- you'll get used to it.' What do you do?

options.label: Accept it as normal -- your colleague has been here for years and they seem fine.
Report the symptoms to your manager and ask for a workstation assessment.
Buy a back support belt from the chemist and wear it during shifts.

ignore_symptoms.text:
Over the next two months, the back pain becomes chronic and the wrist numbness worsens. You start dropping things and can't grip properly. Your GP diagnoses early-stage carpal tunnel syndrome and a lumbar strain.

You're signed off work for six weeks. Because you never reported the symptoms, your employer had no opportunity to adjust your tasks or workstation. The same problems continue for new starters after you.

What should you have done?

options.label: Reported the symptoms immediately and requested an assessment.

report_early.text:
Your manager takes your report seriously and arranges a workstation assessment. The assessment reveals:

- Your pot-wash sink is too low, causing you to stoop for hours.
- The repetitive scrubbing motion is straining your wrist.
- You've been lifting heavy pots from floor level without using the pot stand.

**Actions taken:**
- A raised platform is added to the pot-wash area.
- Task rotation is introduced so you alternate between washing, carrying, and prep.
- You're shown proper stretching exercises for before and after shifts.
- The pot stand is moved to a more accessible position.

**Key lesson**: Early reporting of MSD symptoms triggers early intervention. Under the Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999, your employer must assess and control risks to health -- but they can only do this if they know about the problem.

belt_only.text:
Back support belts are NOT a substitute for proper manual handling technique. The HSE does not recommend back belts as a control measure because:

- They give a **false sense of security**, leading people to lift more than they should.
- They **do not prevent** back injuries.
- They can **restrict breathing** and increase blood pressure.
- They **do not address the root cause** of the problem.

The belt makes you feel better temporarily, but the underlying issues (poor workstation height, repetitive strain, improper lifting) remain unchanged.

What should you do instead?

options.label: Report the symptoms and ask for a proper workstation assessment.
Keep wearing the belt and hope it improves over time.
